answers.answer: To answer your questions:1) A sigmoidoscopy can look for polyps or cancer on the lower left colon.  However, if there continues to be concern or suspicion, a colonoscopy would need to be done.2) Mucous in the stool can be due to chronic pancreatitis or malabsorption.  Blood testing of the amylase and lipase levels and stool analysis can be done if suspected.3) Diabetes can indeed lead to constipation.  I am not aware of fatty liver leading to the symptoms.4) I am not aware of dehydration, diabetes or a fatty liver leading to mucous in the stool.5) The sigmoidoscopy would evaluate the sigmoid colon and below.  Ulcerative colitis would also be seen if present.6) I would consider a colonoscopy at this point for a more thorough evaluation of the colon.These questions can be discussed with your personal physician.Followup with your personal physician is essential.This answer is not intended as and does not substitute for medical advice - the information presented is for patients education only. Please see your personal physician for further evaluation of your individual case.Kevin, M.D.www.kevinmd.com

I wouldn't give you medical advice (even if I am able), because it is obviously a bad thing to do.Just as a fellow-sufferer, I have gone through a lot of stuff like what you describe, and though it IS important for us to get a *doctor* to run the appropriate test and to insist that they get to the bottom of things- in a reasonable way. ( rarely, they can find something serious).  But a lot of times, the situation is hard ball-like stool causing irritation, small tearing, mucus, and blood to appear.  This can scare people, and doctors shouldn't just dismiss it, because rarely, weird things happen.But with bright blood, a small amount, itching, former finding of hemorrhoids....I just wouldn't be "terrified," since that sounds more like a hemorrhoid than something more serious.  I wouldn't be "terrified" even if more  things were going on (I guess that's because I went through a lot of very very serious stuff - totally unrelated to the symptoms described)Anyway, that is *only* an opinion, and even if it is a h., they often need your doctor to do some treatment.Peace &Prayer"abe"
